conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start from rest at the same time and place, moving in the same direction.
Velocity-time graph shows velocities in terms of v0 and time in terms of t0, with markings up to 6t0.
Particle A has a triangular velocity profile peaking at 2v0 at t0, decreasing to zero by 2t0.
Particle B's velocity increases linearly to v0 at 4t0, stays at v0 until 5t0, then decreases to zero by 6t0.
Meeting means particles are at the same position again at some time.
In a velocity-time graph, the area under the curve represents displacement.
To find when they meet, compare their positions over time and see where position graphs intersect.
Integrate velocity functions from time 0 to time t to find positions.
Find velocity equations for particle A: 0 to t0: v_A(t) = (2v0/t0) * t; t0 to 2t0: v_A(t) = 2v0 - (2v0/t0) * (t - t0).
Find velocity equations for particle B: 0 to 4t0: v_B(t) = (v0/(4t0)) * t; 4t0 to 5t0: v_B(t) = v0; 5t0 to 6t0: v_B(t) = v0 - (v0/t0) * (t - 5t0).
Integrate velocity of particle A from 0 to t0: x_A(t) = v0 * (t^2 / t0).
Integrate velocity of particle A from t0 to 2t0.
